headline: 'A slap in the face to the voters': Voto Latino launches campaign to replace Sen. Kyrsten Sinema
author: Javier Arce
sentences:
Sinema: 'Latino community has been a powerful partner'
Despite the criticism, Sinema has remained firm in her decisions and defends herself by arguing that what she has done so far is to support — in large part — the Latino community, including voting rights.

While we take no pleasure in this announcement, the ADP Executive Board has decided to formally censure Sen. Sinema as a result of her failure to do whatever it takes to ensure the health of our democracy," said Arizona Democratic Party Chair Raquel Terán.

“It is a very hypocritical situation for them (Republicans), where they feel very offended by the elimination of the filibuster when they repeatedly violate political conventions to achieve their political and economic goals,” Cornejo said.

One of them is Carmen Cornejo, a political analyst based in Arizona, who told La Voz she has a hard time understanding why Sinema has taken a turn in her way of doing politics, after years of displaying her support for the Latino community.

Ruben Gallego, a potential contender in 2024
Nathalie Rayes, president and CEO of Latino Victory, a progressive organization that works to increase the political power of Latinos, sees Gallego as a great bet for a seat in the U.S. Senate.

“It is definitely not in her interest to lose the support of the Latino community because we are becoming a more important bloc, we are becoming more organized and we try to activate young people who are going to vote for the first time.

campaign, the founder and president of Voto Latino, Maria Teresa Kumar, wrote that Latino leaders from both Washington and Arizona repeatedly contacted Sinema to urge her to protect the constitutional right of the people to cast a vote.

Her failure to move against the filibuster, her rejection of an increase to the minimum wage and her opposition to providing economic relief to undocumented immigrants are three major strikes against the senator, Sandoval said.

According to Sandoval, one of the strongest contenders to potentially run against Sinema is Rep. Ruben Gallego — a bid he's yet to confirm publicly, but Sandoval clarified that Voto Latino does not endorse candidates.

She points out that as a border state, Arizona's economy, culture and history have been shaped by the Latino community, and that community has been a powerful and important partner in her work in the Senate.

Sandoval said the decisions that Sen. Kyrsten Sinema has made as a representative of Arizonans are contrary to the interests of minorities, especially Latinos in the state who supported her with their vote.

“Her choices in the Senate have time and time again been against the constituents of the Latino community, and we are holding her accountable as we move forward to the 2024 election cycle,” Sandoval said.

Another example she gave of her support for Latinos was her push for the bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, which, she said, will create jobs and nurture opportunities for Latino families.

"Input from Arizonans drive my work every single day, and Arizona’s Latino community has been a powerful partner in crafting legislation expanding economic opportunities throughout our state," she said.

Sinema said she backs the Freedom to Vote Act and the John Lewis Voting Rights Act and called the filibuster a “critical tool” for safeguarding democracy in a nation bitterly divided by tribal politics.
As an organization, we focus on supporting Latino politicians, and I think that the things that Sinema has done do not represent what the people of Arizona sent her to the Senate to do,” Rayes said.
However, she has disappointed Democrats, community leaders, activists and her constituents by not voting to eliminate the filibuster, which would open the door to approve voter rights legislation.
“Historically, Native Americans, Latinos, African Americans, low-income people have less access to the vote, and it is easier for groups of power of the Republican Party to block this access."
Voto Latino's plans are to organize activists and community leaders to take to the streets, and spending time talking to the Latino community while encouraging them to get out and vote.
Latino Victory recently endorsed Arizona gubernatorial candidate Marco Lopez, and has done the same with other prominent Arizona politicians such as Adrian Fontes and Daniel Hernandez.
“We are also here to advocate for our constituents, and the ramifications of failing to pass federal legislation that protects their right to vote are too large and far-reaching.
"Most likely, her Republican challenger would be further to the right than Sinema herself and we really don't want a Trump envoy, or a QAnon occupying that seat," Cornejo said.
campaign, political analyst Carmen Cornejo said pushing voters to never vote for Sinema again could also be dangerous if she wins the Democratic nomination for the seat.
"Our historic plan will make Arizona stronger and safer, create millions of good-paying jobs, and expand economic opportunities for Latino families," the senator said.
That’s why I strongly support and have voted to pass all voting rights bills the Senate has recently considered," the senator said in an emailed statement to La Voz.
If the Senate Democrats had eliminated it by a majority, they could have moved on to the next step and attempted to pass legislation such as the voting rights bill.
We know that the Latino vote is very powerful, it is a powerful majority and it is thanks to the Latino vote that we have Joe Biden in the White House,” Rayes said.
campaign, Sinema's office said she supports the minimum wage increase and added that she voted in favor of providing stimulus payments for mixed-status families.

Regarding her vote in the Senate on the filibuster issue, the senator delivered a speech on the floor on Jan. 13 in which she made her position clear.
“Ruben Gallego is a phenomenal Latino, a hardworking congressman from Arizona, who knows how to represent Arizona in Congress,” Rayes said.

For Cornejo, one of the senator's less wise decisions was having opposed the elimination of the filibuster.
